intro: Serratula leucantha var. mucronata, commonly known as the white spearwort, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Europe. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright, branching stems covered in fine, white hairs. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in dense, terminal clusters, which bloom from June to August. Its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and often have a serrated edge, contributing to its botanical classification. It thrives in dry, sunny habitats and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky slopes.
